Critic's Picks | Visual arts

Arts writer Elizabeth Kramer suggests 'Project 5: Stranger Than Function' and Kentucky Fine Art Gallery

Critic's Picks | Visual arts

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 8:21 a.m. EST November 14, 2014

View of art instllation that is part of Zephyr Gallery’s “Stranger Than Function.” (Photo: Courtesy: Zephyr Gallery)

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE


WHAT'S YOUR FUNCTION?

Since arriving in Louisville and stepping into a one-year stint as the Louisville Commission on Public Art's first public arts consultant in 2010, Yasmeen Siddiqui has shown a deep curiosity about the local visual arts community and looked for ways to link it with others. The curator launched a quest to find artists new to Louisville for her latest venture, curating the exhibit "Project 5: Stranger Than Function." With it, she brings Louisville the work of Matt Lynch and Chris Vorhees to Zephyr Gallery. Most of the pieces are installation art, and some are ones the artists collaborated on. The two met at Ball State University in 1989 and have since worked together under the collective Simparch founded in New Mexico. Much of their work references how home design can become absurd in our aspirations for style. "It's funny. It's precise. It's totally thoughtful, beautifully executed — and still heartfelt," said Siddiqui of the work in the show.

WHEN: Through Dec. 20. First Friday Trolley Hop reception, 6-9 p.m. Dec. 5. Artist and curator conversation, 6-7 p.m. Dec. 6.

WHERE: Zephyr Gallery, 610 E. Market St.

COST: Free admission

INFORMATION: (502) 585-5646; zephyrgallery.org

COURIER-JOURNAL

Art exhibits to check out this week


“Racing.Red” by David Schuster, one of the exhibiting artists at Kentucky Fine Art Gallery (Photo: Courtesy: Kentucky Fine Art Gallery)

NEW GALLERY

Several months ago, four Kentucky artists — Jaime Corum, Lynn Dunbar, Robert Halliday and David Schuster — joined forces to launch a new gallery. Called Kentucky Fine Art Gallery, the exhibition space next to Leslie Spetz Framing in Glenview Pointe Center presents a rotating show with diverse work from these artists. Corum, who has been riding and drawing horses since she was a young girl, is now an equine oil painter. Dunbar has garnered several awards for her painting of landscapes and riverscapes in plein air and for her impressionistic pieces. Halliday works in a variety of media and has two watercolors in the Evansville Museum's 57th Mid-States Art Exhibition. David Schuster creates abstract and primarily realistic paintings that include people, landscapes and horses. His painting of horses called "The Fourth Turn" is featured on a commemorative Woodford Reserve bottle unveiled for the 2014 Kentucky Derby. The artists plan to hold special events, such as demonstrations, classes and parties.

WHEN: Continuous

WHERE: Glenview Pointe Center, 2400 Lime Kiln Lane, Suite C.

COST: Free admission

INFORMATION: (502) 426-8880; www.lesliespetzcustomframing.com; Kentucky Fine Art Gallery on Facebook
